hackathon-description-text: Biola Hacks is a two-day, overnight beginner friendly hackathon event! Whether you're a software programmer or designer all are welcome. Come together to collaborate and innovate with a team to solve problems and create something amazing.
hackathon-eligibility:
We welcome all college students of any major
This is a beginner friendly event but we encourage anyone who has had any programming, UI, or project management skills
hackathon-rules:
* Must have Student ID or Government-Issued ID to enter.
* You must be present at Biola Hacks to submit a hack.
* Please do not bring alcoholic beverages / drugs / weapons of any sort. Failure to obey will lead to removal from Biola University site. (Non-alcoholic beverages, food, & snacks are permitted. )
* Must abide by Biola University's 
* You cannot work on your project before hacking begins (which is officially 10:00am PT on Saturday, May 13th), which means all hacks must be made on site.
* You cannot steal another team's source code
* The decision of judges is final for determining prizes and awards.
* Please comply with all instructions from Biola Hacks organizers

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: - Choice of Amazon Echo Dot or Rasberry Pi

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=13800 Biola Ave, La Mirada, CA 90639, USA

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: At the end of the competition, you will be prompted to set up your project at an assigned table. There you will present your 5-minute pitch to the judges. Remember to leave time for questions. Your team will be judged on the following criteria:
Does your hack scream innovation? Is it more than a generic social / mobile / or local hack? Does it take a fresh approach to a new problem?

Technology was meant to make an impact, not keep the world at a standstill. We look for hacks that have large social impact as well as general practicality. Is the hack practical? Is the hack impactful? Does it fulfill a real need people have?

Is the hack technically interesting or difficult to develop? Is it a simple API mashup or is it a comprehensive effort that leverages advanced architecture, tough algorithms, and various libraries and languages?

Clean and seamless hacks are hard to come-by. Is the hack usable and functional in its current state? Does everything appear to work as intended? Does it deliver a beautiful experience? Is it mostly bug-free?

hackathon-location-address: 13800 Biola Ave, La Mirada, CA 90639, USA
